title: CHIP (CT in Head Injury Patients) Prediction Rule
description: Predicts need for CT imaging in patients with minor head trauma to detect potential intracranial injuries

parameters.name: pedestrian_cyclist_vehicle
parameters.description: Pedestrian or cyclist struck by vehicle

parameters.name: ejected_from_vehicle
parameters.description: Patient ejected from vehicle during accident

result.name: chip_recommendation
result.description: CT imaging recommendation based on CHIP criteria

ranges.interpretation: No major or minor criteria met. CT imaging not indicated based on CHIP rule. Continue clinical observation and provide discharge instructions.
One or more major criteria present. CT imaging strongly recommended to evaluate for intracranial traumatic findings.

ranges.description: Moderate to high risk for intracranial injury
ranges.interpretation: Two or more minor criteria present. CT imaging recommended to evaluate for potential intracranial traumatic findings.

ranges.description: Low to moderate risk for intracranial injury
ranges.interpretation: One minor criterion present. Consider CT imaging based on clinical judgment, patient factors, and physician preference.

references: Smits M, Dippel DW, de Haan GG, Dekker HM, Vos PE, Kool DR, et al. External validation of the Canadian CT Head Rule and the New Orleans Criteria for CT scanning in patients with minor head injury. JAMA. 2005 Sep 28;294(12):1519-25.

Smits M, Dippel DW, Steyerberg EW, de Haan GG, Dekker HM, Vos PE, et al. Predicting intracranial traumatic findings on computed tomography in patients with minor head injury: the CHIP prediction rule. Ann Intern Med. 2007 Mar 6;146(6):397-405.

van den Brand CL, Rambach AH, Postma K, et al. Update of the CHIP (CT in Head Injury Patients) decision rule for patients with minor head injury based on a multicenter consecutive case series. Emerg Med J. 2022 Dec;39(12):897-902.
formula: Decision based on presence of major criteria (any one triggers CT) or minor criteria (≥2 trigger CT)
notes: Applicable to patients ≥16 years old with minor head injury
Should be applied within 24 hours of blunt head trauma
Rule should support, not replace, clinical judgment
Original sensitivity 100% for neurosurgical interventions with 23-30% specificity
